title: 106_hr4735
content: The Act titled "Wartime Parity and Justice Act of 2000" allows certain individuals to be eligible under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988. Eligibility criteria for individuals under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 include being of Japanese ancestry, forcibly brought to the US from Central or South America during a specific period, living on August 10, 1988, meeting specific requirements, and not having received prior payment under the Act. An individual eligible for payment under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 includes those who were eligible before this Act but did not receive payment, individuals born to eligible individuals during a specific period and living on August 10, 1988. An individual eligible for payment under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 includes those of Japanese ancestry who were citizens or permanent residents, had their employment terminated due to their ancestry, were dependent children of eligible individuals, and were living on August 10, 1988. An individual eligible for payment under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 must meet specific requirements related to Japanese ancestry and legal status during the evacuation period. Additionally, individuals sent to Japan in exchange for prisoners during a specific time frame are not excluded from eligibility. The United States apologizes for violating the civil liberties and constitutional rights of individuals during the evacuation, relocation, or internment period. The President will send a personal letter of apology to each affected individual. The Civil Liberties Act of 1988 provisions apply to eligible individuals under this Act. The Attorney General is responsible for identifying and locating eligible individuals within 12 months of enactment. Eligible individuals can notify the Attorney General of their status. The Attorney General determines eligibility of individuals under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 within 1 year of locating or receiving notification. Eligible individuals can seek judicial review of compensation denial within 6 years. Payments from court cases are allowed under certain circumstances. Payments from court cases can be received by individuals eligible under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988, with certain conditions. Any previous payments from final judgments or settlements will reduce the amount payable under the Act. SEC. 5. CORRECTION OF IMMIGRATION STATUS. Individuals in paragraph (1) of section 2(a) are not considered unlawfully present in the US during evacuation, relocation, or internment. US departments must correct records indicating unlawful presence during that period. SEC. 6. FULL DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION. SEC. 6. FULL DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION. The US government must disclose all information related to the forcible removal and internment of individuals from Central and South America during a specific period. This includes sharing information with other countries. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund is reestablished in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Amounts in the Fund will be invested according to specified regulations and used for payments to eligible individuals and by the Board of Directors. Appropriations are authorized as necessary for Fund operations. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund is reestablished in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Appropriations of $45,000,000 are authorized for disbursements by the Board of Directors under section 8. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund is reestablished and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. $45,000,000 in appropriations are authorized for disbursements by the Board of Directors. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund Board of Directors is established to make disbursements for research and public education activities related to the evacuation, relocation, and internment of individuals of Japanese ancestry. The Fund can also be used for administrative expenses of the Board. The provisions of section 106 of the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 apply to the Board of the Fund established for research and public education on the evacuation, relocation, and internment of Japanese Americans. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. The terms "evacuation, relocation, or internment period" and "permanent resident alien" are defined in section 108 of the Civil Liberties Act of 1988.
